Award.AwardTitle: Control of Adult Patterning during Metamorphosis
Award.AbstractNarration: In recent decades it has become clear that animal development is remarkably parsimonious, with the same underlying regulators being used repeatedly to pattern different structures at different stages of the life cycle. In large part, this parsimony is achieved by changes over time in the responsiveness of target genes to these regulators. Such changes explain how the same regulator can activate or repress distinct sets of target genes at different stages of development. The goal of this research is to understand how target gene responsiveness is controlled during the life cycle. The focus of the work is insect metamorphosis, a process known to involve global shifts in such responsiveness. The work tests the hypothesis that pupa-specific target responsiveness in Drosophila is controlled by the E93 gene. E93 encodes a gene regulator that is expressed specifically at the pupal stage, and is required for most or all patterning processes that occur at this time. E93 is known to function during leg development to control the pupa-specific responsiveness of the Dll gene. This work tests whether other genes that change their responsiveness in the pupa are also regulated by E93, and determine the molecular mechanisms by which E93 acts. An understanding of how E93 controls target gene responsiveness will have broad significance, as similar mechanisms likely direct life cycle transitions in many other organisms, including ourselves. The work includes outreach activity at a local high school. In a project to characterize the evolution of E93, students will collect and classify local insects, purify their DNA, and conduct phylogenetic studies of the E93 gene. After a year of piloting, the project will be expanded to include selected schools within the city of St. Louis, engaging students who otherwise would have little or no exposure to research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Whether transitioning from larva to pupa, or child to adolescent, animals proceed through distinct stages during their development.  In some cases, these transitions can result in dramatic changes in body form.  How do such transformations occur?  In recent decades, it has become clear that the same basic tool kit of patterning signals is responsible for producing both adult and juvenile forms.  What changes from one stage to the next is whether or not cells are competent to respond to these signals.  How such changes in competence are controlled is poorly understood.  Our long-term goal is to understand the mechanisms involved.  We have identified the Eip93F(E93) gene, which encodes a DNA-binding regulatory protein, as a key determinant of pupa-specific competence during metamorphosis in the fruit fly Drosophila.  E93is expressed only at the pupal stage, and almost all patterning processes that normally occur in the pupa fail in E93mutants.  In prior work, we carried out a detailed study of one E93-dependent process, the induction of bracts (small cuticular outgrowths) by bristle cells in the pupal leg.  In this work, we showed that E93functions to activate the competence of a bract-specific regulatory element of the Dllgene, which specifies bract fate.  Generalizing from this finding, our central hypothesis has been that E93functions globally to control pupa-specific patterning by controlling the competence of regulatory DNA throughout the genome. Our two main research goals have been: 1) to assess genome-wide the degree to which E93is required for pupa-specific changes in the competence of regulatory DNA, and 2) to determine how E93functions to control the competence of its targets.  An additional goal has been to engage biology students at a local high school in a project to explore the evolution of E93.

Since competence is very often associated with increased chromatin accessibility, we addressed the first goal by comparing accessibility profiles in wild-type and E93-mutant tissues from staged pupae.  The results indicate that thousands of sites undergo increases or decreases in accessibility during the transition from larval to pupal stages, and that a large fraction of these changes fail to occur in E93-mutant pupae.  We find that E93protein binds at many of the sites that undergo E93-dependent accessibility changes.  However, many such sites do not appear to be bound by E93, suggesting that E93acts indirectly to control competence at many locations.  A key experiment was to determine the effects of expressing E93in larval tissues, prior to the normal time of E93expression.  We were surprised to find that such precocious expression of E93has almost no effect on chromatin accessibility. These experiments indicate that E93is not able to alter chromatin accessibility on its own, and likely works with other pupa-specific factors to control competence.

To determine the mechanisms by which E93controls competence, we have focused on two regulatory regions: the bract-specific regulator from the Dllgene and a wing-vein-specific regulator from the dppgene.  Both regulatory regions are competent only in the pupa, and require E93for function.  We have identified two small subfragments of the bract regulator that drive expression in bracts at the pupal stage and that retain complete E93dependence.  Within the wing-vein regulatory region, we have identified six regions that bind E93. Short fragments containing each of these sites drive expression in subsets of the wing-vein pattern in pupae (see figure).  Experiments to test the interactions of E93and other factors with the bract and wing-vein regulatory region fragments in vitroare under way.

We have also been engaged in outreach activities at Ladue Horton Watkins High School in St. Louis.  Three biology class sessions were devoted to the project each year.  In the first, students collected insects and other arthropods from a local park.  In a second class, students keyed their specimens out to order, photographed them, and then isolated genomic DNA.  These DNAs were then brought to our lab, where we sequenced a highly conserved E93domain for each.  In a third session, students placed their sequences in a phylogenetic context.  Because students analyze sequences from their own specimens, engagement has been high.
